name: Sacral Nerve Stimulation for the Treatment of Urinary and Fecal Incontinence
description: This policy outlines limited coverage for sacral nerve stimulation (SNS) for the treatment of urinary urge incontinence, urgency-frequency syndrome, nonobstructive urinary retention, and fecal incontinence, with specific details under Coverage Indications, Limitations, and/or Medical Necessity. It also specifies exclusions for certain conditions and for experimental/investigational uses like chronic constipation or chronic pelvic pain.

restrictions.condition: Patient has a diagnosis of urinary urge incontinence.
Patient has a diagnosis of urgency-frequency syndrome.
Patient has a diagnosis of nonobstructive urinary retention.
Patient is refractory to conventional therapy for urinary indications, including documented behavioral, pharmacologic, and/or surgical corrective therapy.
Patient is an appropriate surgical candidate such that implantation with anesthesia can occur.
Patient does not have stress incontinence.
Patient does not have urinary obstruction.
Patient does not have diabetes with peripheral nerve involvement associated with secondary manifestations of urinary incontinence indications.
Patient does not have multiple sclerosis associated with secondary manifestations of urinary incontinence indications.
Patient does not have spinal cord injury associated with secondary manifestations of urinary incontinence indications.
Patient must have had a successful test stimulation with 50% or greater improvement for urinary indications, measured through voiding diaries.
Patient is able to demonstrate adequate ability to record voiding diary data such that clinical results of the implant procedure can be properly evaluated.
Patient has chronic fecal incontinence with greater than 2 incontinent episodes on average per week.
Duration of fecal incontinence is greater than 6 months.
Duration of incontinence is more than 12 months after vaginal childbirth.
Patient has documented failure or intolerance to conventional therapy for fecal incontinence (e.g., dietary modification, bulking, and pharmacologic treatment).
Patient had a successful percutaneous test stimulation with at least 50% sustained improvement for more than 48 hours for fecal incontinence.
Condition is not related to anorectal malformation (e.g., congenital malformation).
Condition is not related to defects of the external anal sphincter over 60 degrees.
Condition is not related to visible sequelae of pelvic radiation.
Condition is not related to active anal abscesses and fistulae.
Condition is not related to chronic inflammatory bowel disease.
Incontinence is not related to peripheral neuropathy.
Incontinence is not related to complete spinal cord injury.
Sacral nerve stimulation is not covered for the treatment of chronic constipation as it is considered experimental/investigational.
Sacral nerve stimulation is not covered for the treatment of chronic pelvic pain (CPP) as it is considered experimental/investigational.
Patient's medical record must contain documentation fully supporting medical necessity for services.
Documentation of complete history and physical examination, including voiding diaries and urodynamic studies for urinary incontinence, is required.
Documentation that patient is refractory to conventional therapy is required.
Documentation that patient had a successful test stimulation to support subsequent implantation is required.
